Additionaly writers are also arranged to student during examinations. A well organized Hostel in a rented place for visually impaired boys with free lodging, boarding, medical care, tuition fees and so many other facilities like Water purification system, audio -video system, Refrigerator ,Laptops etc. Achievements- Mr. Nitin Kumar Tyagi got 87 % in class 12 C.B.S.E Board & cleared his IIT entrance exam with 163 rank in GEPWD list in 2016. He is also enrolled in FIITJEE coaching centre from Sept 2016 for IIT entrance exam. Mr. Kiran Kumar Shrestha got an appointment as probationary single window operator in Corporation Bank in April 2016. Mr. Manish kanaujia got a job in Satyawati College in Delhi University as a Assistant Professor ( Hindi subject) in July 2015. Mr. Sonu got 81 % marks in class 12 C.B.S.E Board In 2015. Mr. Jitender Sharma got a job as a Probationary Officer in Punjab & Sind bank in July 2014. Mr. Jitender Kumar got a job as a clerical cadre in Punjab & Sind bank in May 2014. Mr. Ishwar Verma got a job as a Stenographer in Income Tax Department. in Jan 2013. Mr. Sanjeev and Mr Suman have been working as a school teacher in govt. recognized school.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: The mission of the I CAN WIN FOUNDATION is "Win over Cancer". At the I CAN WIN FOUNDATION, we are working at the grass root level in India to change the way cancer is perceived by the society and in the process to win over cancer. The Association wishes to partner with other organizations to achieve the goal envisioned to make cancer a National priority. To build a National grassroots movement that will take cancer from isolation to collaboration. A professional-public-patient partnership model to build awareness and screening centers at smaller towns and cities to help local people for easy assess to information for cancer. To end the stigma of cancer and turn cancer victims into Cancer â€œWinnersâ€. Association brings together individuals and professionals to carry out programmes in â€¢ Cancer awareness in public and health care-takers â€¢ Cancer prevention and control â€¢ Cancer supportive care and rehabilitation programs â€¢ Tobacco control ; â€˜I CAN WINâ€™ organizes Workshops, Round table discussions, Conferences & Rehabilitation camps to achieve all its Goal. To know more about our recent activities please visit www.icanwinassociation.blogspot.com/

sourceOfFunds.purpose: DDU-GKY is uniquely focused on rural youth between the ages of 15 and 35 years from poor families. As a part of the Skill India campaign, it plays an instrumental role in supporting the social and economic programs of the government like the Make In India, Digital India, Smart Cities and Start-Up India, Stand-Up India campaigns. Over 180 million or 69% of the country’s youth population between the ages of 18 and 34 years, live in its rural areas.

Development Support Agency of Gujarat (D?SAG), an autonomous society promoted under the Tribal Development Department (TDD), Government of Gujarat, is implementing Employment Oriented Skill Training Programme in 14 ITDP districts of Gujarat. Sustainable livelihood generation for tribal youth through enhancement of skills all the way through Employment Oriented Skill Training Programme is one of the programs under Vanbandhu Kalyan Yojana

Rajasthan is the first State in India to establish a Mission on Livelihoods. In order to address the challenges of unemployment and ensuring gainful and sustainable employment to the youth of the state, Hon’ble Chief Minister created Rajasthan Mission on Livelihood (RMoL) in September 2004. The objective of creation of RMoL was to formulate appropriate and innovative strategies to promote and facilitate large scale livelihoods for the poor and vulnerable people of the state.

sourceOfFunds.purpose: In Delhi, we have helped the families of underprivileged students get into private schools under the Right to Education Act (RTE) section 12(1)(c). With only two full time employees and over 500 volunteers in the 1st year, we mark ourselves as volunteer based organization with heavy emphasis of technology inventions and unique partnerships which has enabled us to get this model on the ground and support over 7000 students and their families to get free education in Delhi private schools.

In Delhi and across 4 other states, we have helped the families of underprivileged students get free education in private schools under the Right to Education Act (RTE) section 12(1)(c). We mark ourselves as a technology based organisation with Tech support and unique partnerships at state level which enables us to get over 1 million students and their families free education in Delhi private schools.
Under RTE section 12-1-C, 25% seats in primary grade in private schools and are allocated to low income and disadvantaged students. Indus action mission is to support a million student across India.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Indus Quality Foundation is inspired by the vision that India should be among the leading nations of the world. As children are the future of the world, IQF began as an initiative towards advancement of education on Quality Management in schools, based on the know-how of Quality Improvement, researched and developed by Philip Crosby the Quality Guru. The IQF Mission has been 1. To spread the message and know how of Quality 2. To enable individuals realise their true potential through holistic personality development 3. To bring positive behaviourial change in society. IQF has successfully been able to bring about the concept, meaning and practical measurement of Quality and its improvement in any identified area undertaken in schools. The objective has been to develop increased level of competence, attitude and skills for facing the challenges of the world.Apart from these quality initiatives in schools IQF has been working upon various rural development programmes upon Education, Health, Nutrition and sanitation.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Institute for Human Development The Institute for Human Development (IHD) was established in 1998 under the aegis of the Indian Society of Labour Economics (ISLE) to undertake research and studies in areas relating to labour markets and human development. The Institute is one of the â€˜ICSSR-recognised institutesâ€™, a category of Research Institutions created by the Indian Council of Social Science Research (ICSSR), Government of India. IHD is a non-profit autonomous institution registered under the Societies Registration Act, 1861, and it is recognized by the Ministry of Science and Technology, Government of India, as a Scientific and Industrial Research Organization. Income Tax exemption is available to the Institute under Section 35 (1) (iii). The Institute is also registered under the Foreign Contribution Regulation Act, 1976 (FCRA), and is entitled to receive foreign contributions. Main Thematic Research Areas of the Institute include: â€¢ Growth, labour markets and employment â€¢ Education and capabilities â€¢ Health and nutrition â€¢ Gender and development â€¢ Security and vulnerability â€¢ Governance and institutions Other Activities of the Institute are: â€¢ Organization of seminars, workshops, conferences, consultations, lectures and discussions on issues of academic and policy interest, and contemporary relevance; â€¢ Conduct of courses and training programmes on issues pertaining to human development; â€¢ Networking with other institutions and organizations at regional, national and international levels for facilitating sharing and exchange of information and ideas through joint collaboration and partnership; and â€¢ Publication of journals, research reports, working papers, monographs and books on the above issues. Key Strengths: The Institute has undertaken over 250 research projects, sponsored by both national and international organizations and by the state and central governments; organized over 150 seminars, workshops, conferences and policy dialogues; and implemented training and capacity building activities, including a Ph.D. programme. The Institute also participates in a wide range of networks, both in India and abroad, particularly in South Asia. IHD has Developed a number of competencies, the salient ones being: â€¢ Research in the core dimensions of human development â€“ livelihoods, education and health; â€¢ Primary survey-based research to analyze policy impacts and social and economic change; â€¢ Capacity to mobilize State and non-State actors and engage them in policy debates; â€¢ Ability to provide a critical, independent view on development issues; â€¢ Conversion of research findings into educational and training material; â€¢ Networking at national and international levels; â€¢ High quality publications, including two journals: the Indian Journal of Labour Economics and the Indian Journal of Human Development. The institute has a core group of experienced faculty, besides visiting faculty who are also known academicians and experts from all over the world and various parts of India. In addition, there are a number of research associates who provide support to the faculty and research projects. The Instituteâ€™s wide network enables it to take advantage of the expertise of a number of senior experts and professionals spread all over the country including outside India.

sourceOfFunds.purpose: The political economy of labour market regulations and concomitant institutions has not been systematically studied in India. ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Conducting research has been the most important activity of the Institute. It has completed over 70 study projects, the details of which are available on its website. Most of the research projects undertaken have been sponsored by different ministries of Government of India or international agencies. These generally have dealt with national and state policies oriented issues related to management and development of water resources, rural development and poverty alleviation, environmental preservation, disaster management, gender studies and socio-economic development. A majority of the studies have involved conduct of large scale socio-economic field surveys resulting in collection of primary data. Such surveys have been conducted in almost all parts of India. The studies have also enabled the Institute to gain considerable experience of interaction with government machinery at the central, state, district levels and below. The findings and suggestions of these studies are available in the reports submitted to the respective sponsoring agencies. Conducting training programmes for senior government officers has been another activity of the Institute. Several such programmes including those for senior IAS officers have been conducted. Details provided on the Instituteâ€™s website. These were one or two weeks programmes dealing mostly with optimum utilization of resources veering around economic and environmental analysis of major development projects. Most of the training programmes have been sponsored by the respective ministries of Government of India. The institute has played an active part in organizing international, national as well as state level seminars and conferences on important policy related issues (Details on its website). The most notable among these has been the International Conference on Sustainable Development of Water Resources, in 2000. These have been organized in Delhi as well as in other parts of the country and have generally been sponsored by different ministries of Government of India, State Governments, International and other agencies. These seminars and conferences have been well attended with the right mix of participation from government, academic institutions and NGOs depending upon the context and have come forward with very useful recommendations. Institution building has also been an important activity specially in the earlier years. The Institute established a spacious office complex of its own with all the requisite facilities such as office and staff rooms, computer rooms, library, seminar hall, computers, LCD projector etc. located in a well connected institutional area and surrounded by a host of public institutions. Allotment of land for the same was got approved by Delhi Development Authority while, the Ministry of Finance, Government of India, agreed to our request to provide a major grant for construction of the office complex. The Institute also succeeded in getting 80G sanctioned by the Income Tax Authorities. The Institute established a rich library which can be used by outside scholars, professionals and students also. Since 2002,the Institute has also set up a study centre for BCA students within its office complex sponsored by Indira Gandhi National Open University (IGNOU). This centre is equipped with 30 desktop computers and other facilities.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Seminars on Bio fuel & Green Energy for Sustainable Growth and Impact on Climate Change The Institute of Applied System and Rural Development IASRD has taken up awareness program for promotion of bio fuel for sustainable growth to compliment the efforts in ensuring energy security of the Nation. To achieve this objective the Institute has organized 11 seminars in 11 states namely: 1st Seminar was held at Delhi 2nd seminar at Nashik Maharastra 3rd seminar at Anand Gujarat 4th seminar at Lucknow UP 5th seminar at Bangalore Karnataka 6th seminar at Raipur Chhattisgarh 7th seminar at Dhanbad Jharkhand 8th seminar at Haridwar Uttarakhand 9th seminar at Jodhpur Rajasthan 10th seminar at Patna Bihar& 11th seminar at Aizwal Mizoram. The basic objective of the seminar is to promote awareness for increasing the use of Bio fuel & Green Energy to ensure energy security for sustainable. The objective activities like Seminar & awareness programmes were financially supported in the form of Grants in aid by the various Ministries like of Earth Sciences Ministry of New & Renewal Energy MNRE. Ministry of Rural Development & also sponsored by the Govt. Oil Companies like IOC HPCL & BPCL. Institute has also organized Awareness program for School Children on Impact of Climate Change & their Role to mitigate it in Raipur district of Chhattisgharh, Haridwar district in Uttarakhand and Gautam budh Nagar in UP. Fourth program has been conducted last year in Anand district of Gujarat. The primary objective of the programme is to sensitize and encourage the students of 6th to 10th standards in the age group of 10 to 17 for their active participation in mitigation of climate change and to help them to learn, understand and address the impacts of global warming today, at the same time encouraging the change in their attitudes and behavior needed to put up efforts on a more sustainable path in the future. Undoubtedly the climate change is going to effect the next generation adversely. It is therefore necessary to initiate action to arrest the change in deteriorating climate now. The children hence need to be mainstreamed into larger debates on climate change, hazards and vulnerabilities with an overview of the linkages between climate change and sustainable development which is threatened by increasing frequency of hazardous weather and the inability of the poor and most vulnerable to adapt to climate variability and extremes. The awareness programme on Climate Change is linked with the Tree Plantation Programme.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: The Institute of Social Sciences was registered on 28 August 1985 under the Societies Registration Act, 1860. The Institute commenced its journey with the objective â€œto study contemporary social political and economic issues and problems, in an interdisciplinary perspective and to make available its findings and recommendations to government bodies, social scientists, policy makers, peopleâ€™s and workersâ€™ organizations, so as to widen their options for action. The evolution of an informed and action-oriented public opinion is the primary aim of the Institute.â€The Institute takes considerable pride both in its research and advocacy work. As a Ford Foundation document puts it, the Institute of Social Sciences is â€œa leading centre which has a strong legitimacy among senior policy-makers, bureaucrats and politicians. It regularly hosts high-profile meetings and workshops for policy-makers, training institutions and leading non-governmental organizations.â€ The ISS has created a niche both among policy-makers and civil society through its numerous researches; advocacy through conferences, seminars and workshops; and monitoring through public interest litigations and other more direct forms of interventions. Academicians, political leaders including those holding ministerial ranks or constitutional positions, public servants, and social workers have joined hands and lent their support to the Instituteâ€™s efforts in the field of local self-government. The Institute grew over the years and eventually moved to its new premises. The then Vice-President of India Shri K R Narayanan laid the foundation stone of the building on 7 October 1994 at Nelson Mandela Road, Vasant Kunj. The building having a total built-up area of 13,211 sq.ft was completed in 1998 and the ISS finally shifted to its new premises in May 1999.The generous financial contributions from various State governments, countries, international bodies and individuals amounting to over Rs.2.50 crores speak volumes for the enormous goodwill, professional competence and legitimacy that the ISS acquired in such a short span of its life. The Institute has developed a computerised library and documentation centre in the new building. The centre has established a network with institutions engaged in similar areas of study as well as with local government bodies in the various states. Government and non-government organisations, international agencies, U.N. organisations are seeking the help of the Institute for data on local government system. Research scholars and students from India and abroad visit our library for reference. The role of the ISS attracted groups of scholars and activists in other States which led to the birth of new centres of ISS. The first centre was established in Bangalore in 1994 which was followed by centres in Bhubaneswar (1999), Kolkata (2002) and Thiruvanthapuram (2003). Each Centre was demand-driven from the respective regions. They lobbied for their projects independently of the ISS at Delhi. The Institute is currently at an important phase of its further development. It is also redefining the thrust areas for research and other interventions, in order to provide a definitive meaning and direction to its future course of action.
